checkpoint-1.caption: Students can access document content, regardless of their sensory abilities.

table.task: Apply heading styles (Heading 1, Heading 2, etc.) for document structure instead of manually formatted text.
Add alternative text to all images to describe important visual content.
Ensure sufficient color contrast between text and background.
Avoid using color alone to convey information or meaning.
Include descriptive header rows in tables and label them clearly.
Use meaningful link text instead of generic phrases like 'Click here'.
Provide captions or additional context for important images and diagrams.
Avoid using tables for layout purposes.

checkpoint-2.caption: Students can navigate and interact with documents regardless of how they use computers.

table.task: Maintain logical document structure using headings in proper hierarchical order.
Use built-in bulleted and numbered lists instead of manually typed symbols.
Avoid excessive indentation or manual spacing for layout purposes.
Support visuals with text descriptions or context so meaning isn't conveyed by visuals alone.
Create a table of contents for longer documents to help with navigation.

checkpoint-3.caption: Students can easily understand the content and navigate through documents.

table.task: Write in clear, concise language appropriate to students' reading level.
Define new or difficult vocabulary when first introduced.
Maintain consistent formatting with uniform font sizes and styles throughout the document.
Avoid mixing colors or fonts excessively.
Label assignments, steps, or sections clearly with consistent formatting.
Keep sentences short and age-appropriate for the intended audience.

checkpoint-4.caption: Students can access documents using different technologies and tools that help them learn.

table.task: Run an accessibility checker like Grackle Docs to identify and fix issues.
Export and share documents in accessible formats like Google Docs, tagged PDFs, or HTML.
Simplify table structures and provide summaries for complex tables if needed.
Avoid complex nested layouts that may confuse screen readers.
Ensure document properties like title are properly set for easier identification.
